name: Immanuel Kant
spiralJustification: Enlightenment thinker bridging systematic order (Blue) and rational progress (Orange)
comprehensiveBiography: Immanuel Kant (1724-1804) was a German philosopher and one of the central Enlightenment thinkers. Kant's comprehensive and systematic works in epistemology, metaphysics, ethics, and aesthetics have made him one of the most influential figures in modern Western philosophy.
intellectualJourney: Kant's critical philosophy emerged from his attempt to bridge the gap between rationalism and empiricism, leading to his revolutionary 'Copernican turn' in philosophy.

name: Aristotle
comprehensiveBiography: Aristotle (384-322 BCE) was an Ancient Greek philosopher and scientist who made important contributions to logic, criticism, rhetoric, physics, biology, psychology, mathematics, metaphysics, ethics, and politics.
intellectualJourney: Student of Plato who developed his own systematic philosophy emphasizing empirical observation and logical categorization of knowledge.

name: Friedrich Nietzsche
spiralJustification: Individual value creation (Orange) moving toward perspectivism and pluralism (Green)
comprehensiveBiography: Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) was a German philosopher, cultural critic, and philologist whose work has exerted a profound influence on modern intellectual history.
intellectualJourney: From classical philology to radical critique of traditional values, developing ideas of the Übermensch and eternal recurrence.

name: Plato
spiralJustification: Absolute truth seeker emphasizing eternal Forms and hierarchical order
comprehensiveBiography: Plato (c. 428-348 BCE) was a philosopher in Classical Greece and the founder of the Academy in Athens, the first institution of higher learning in the Western world.
intellectualJourney: Student of Socrates who developed the theory of Forms and established the foundation for Western philosophical tradition.

name: René Descartes
spiralJustification: Methodical doubt and scientific rationalism exemplify Orange systematic thinking
comprehensiveBiography: René Descartes (1596-1650) was a French philosopher, mathematician, and scientist who is widely considered the father of modern philosophy.
intellectualJourney: Developed method of systematic doubt leading to cogito ergo sum and establishment of methodical rationalism.
